content:
You would pay your internet service provider for broadband access to internet. The internet service provider usually offers a free email address and sometimes additional ones as part of the package. You can view those emails via the ISP webmail account using a browser OR you can use an email client such as Thunderbird to access that server and download/send emails using that email address.

You may also have your own website as you own a domain and you pay a company to host that website and they may offer an allowed X number of email addresses. You will be charged eg: annually for domain and also webhosting. Again you can view those emails via webmail OR use Thunderbird.

You may have acquired a free email address via a company that offers them eg: gmail, yahoo, gmx Again you can view those emails via webmail OR use Thunderbird.

In all cases, the server of ISP/webhost/gmail etc facilites receiving of emails on your behalf. They will permit a quota limit for storage. Whether you choose to download a copy of emails and keep original on server or delete original off server is your choice. Keeping copy on server does mean you can use Imap mail accounts.

If you have Pop mail accounts then any emails you have downloaded are stored on your computer. Pop accounts do not synchronise with server, so emails are an independent copy. If you have an Imap account then you cannot consider those downloaded emails as a true copy on computer because it can only show what is one server. All imap folders sycnhronise with server to show what is currently on server. You would need to create suitable folders in 'Local Folders' mail account and get 'Copys' of emails in imap folders put into those folders. Then you can say you have an independent copy on your computer.

Thunderbird is an email client; a program running on your computer to faciliate the management of viewing all mail accounts in a single view. It also offeres sending of email and other facilities such as viewing calendars.

Thunderbird is not a server nor does it offer hosting of websites etc.

Nothing is free. It costs to run servers whether that is for website or receiving emails. If you have domain names, websites etc that you no longer need or want etc then remove them after ensuring you have good copies of all emails in Thunderbird on computer.

There are companies where you can try to just have the email address not host a website. But maybe it's time you rationalised what you need to keep.

Thunderbird used to have a link with a couple of business partners who could offer new email addresses. Obviously you would need to pay for those email addresses. Those options seems to have been removed since Nebula was released. But the companies still exist - you could check them out.

I cannot endorse anything as I've never used them. But these are a couple of link you can check out to see if it offers you what you are looking for. Needless to say any email address you create can also then be added as a new existing mail account in Thunderbird.

https://www.gandi.net/en/domain/email https://mailfence.com/
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
One of the most common reasons for this is an Anti-Virus because it's scanning incoming files and also maybe scanning any file that gets opened and updated with new mail. Files get downloaded and then appended to relevant file eg: Inbox mbox file.

Advise: make your thunderbird profile folder and it's contents is exempt from being scanning. Also switch off scanning of incoming files/emails - even if this is just for a day or two to test performance.

One quick way to ensure a proper test is to do the following so AV and other similar types of programs are temp disabled without the need to alter anything: Exit all programs Restart computer in 'safe mode with networking' - note - if currently wireless using WIFI then you will need to connect computer to router/hub using an ethernet cable. Then start Thunderbird and see if things improve.

Another main reason for delays are files containing emails which are getting rather large, so take up memory etc when they get opened to write data into. If you have a lot of emails in some folders then suggest you create some new folders with suitable names for organising and storing mail. Then compact folders. I would advise you manually compact certain folders on a regular basis. Any folder that receives mail which is subsequently moved or deleted will still have a copy of email in original folder but it is 'marked as delted' and hidden from view. Compacting means a new file is created and then it looks in the original file for anything 'marked as deleted' - it does not copy those emails - only all the good emails you want to keep are copied into that new file. Then original is removed and new file replaces it. The new version is like a cleaned up file. It's considered good housekeeping maintenance and helps to reduce file size, recover disk space and reduce the risk of corrupt file.

The three folders that usually need compacting the most are 'Inbox', 'Junk/Spam' and 'Drafts'. But also any folder which you know you have deleted or moved a load of emails.

To compact: Right click on folder and select 'Compact'
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Can you please offer some information about your setup because at the moment all I know is you have a computer and an existing password is not recognised.

You have got a new/additional computer. Q: What type of OS, Windows, Mac, Linux ? Q: You have installed Thunderbird, but how did you install it ? Q: Did you download and install from the official website ?

  • https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/

Or did you install via Microsoft app or Snap or Flatpak ?

First make sure 'Thunderbird' has access to internet.

  • Exit Thunderbird.
  • Access Firewall - that might be default that comes with computer or it might be controlled by your Anti-Virus.
  • You need to set up Thunderbird as an allowed program to ensure it's not being blocked.

Confirm - Thunderbird is set up as an allowed program.


Q: Are you trying to set up exactly the same as you have on the old computer ? Q: Does this mean you want to backup the original data on old computer and put it into the new computer Or do you use Imap accounts, so just need to create an existing mail account on new computer ?

Q: At this point have you created a mail account or not - regardless of whether it is working?

You are obviously getting an error of some type which says 'password is wrong'. Please post an image showing that window and error message. A error with password may mean wrong password or it may mean password is ok but not for the username or password and username are ok but not with those server settings.

I'm assuming you are trying to set up same account as on old computer. You say "Doesn't seem to recognise my manual configuration" Thunderbird has to provide the server settings, username and password which are accepted by server that maintains the account and emails, so they are very specific. However, at this point I have no idea what those server settings are supposed to be. But the following is used. 1. User name = full email address 2. Password is the same password you use to access your account via webmail. There are times when this may be different as some servers now insist on you using an app specific password. But as I do not know what server you are trying to use, I cannot say at this point whether that is the case.

The window that shows you attempting to create a mail account with error message should provide enough data if you have not created mail account just yet.

If you have created a mail account but get password error: On new computer: In Thunderbird

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Scroll down to 'Mail and News Accounts'
  • Copy all the data in that area
  • paste that data into this forum.

Then I will understand what you are currently using for server settings on new computer.

Then On old computer Q: What version of Thunderbird are you using ? In Thunderbird

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Scroll down to 'Mail and News Accounts'
  • Copy all the data in that area
  • paste that data into this forum.

Then I will understand what you are currently using for server settings on old computer.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Esagerato... Non è Thunderbird ad essere impazzito, ma probabilmente un tuo errore nell'aggiungere un contatto alla rubrica. Segui queste indicazioni:

La PEC nel sistema italiano è una particolare email con valore legale. Per ottenere questo risultato la comunicazione tra un mittente MITT ed un destinatario DEST è mediata dal una società abilitata alla gestione della PEC rispondente a precisi requisiti tecnici [1] (GEST). Nelle intestazioni della PEC avremi quindi riferimenti a MITT, DEST e GEST. Supponiamo che DEST, ricevuta una PEC da MITT, voglia aggiungere il mittente alla propria rubrica di Thunderbird. A volte capita che al nome di MITT non vanga associato il relativo indirizzo email ma quello dell'intermediario GEST. Il risultato è che da quel momento in poi tutte le PEC ricevute da utenti di GEST appariranno con mittente MIT, talvolta con la dicitura "per conto di". Per risolvere il problema è necessario cancellare il contatto MITT dalla rubrica. 1. è una semplificazione funzionale al discorso

content:
I've checked the server name etc, but Oauth2 still won't appear in the drop box.

Not sure what you checked.

Your server names as per your Troubleshooting Information: INCOMING: account7, , (imap) imap-mail.outlook.com:993, SSL, 10 OUTGOING: , smtp-mail.outlook.com:587, alwaysSTARTTLS, passwordCleartext, true

The same goes for account8.

Server names required as per the linked article:

Incoming: outlook.office365.com Port: 993 User Name: <your e-mail address> Connection security: SSL/TLS Authentication method: OAuth2

Outgoing: smtp.office365.com Port: 587 User Name: <your e-mail address> Connection security: STARTTLS Authentication method: OAuth2

So you do need to fix the server names in your Server Settings for those accounts (as you've been told twice before by now). Once the server names are correct, you can select OAuth2 for authentication.

content:
I can only send from one account, not from account 8.

What error messages do you get? A screenshot may help. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/how-do-i-create-screenshot-my-problem
creator: christ1

content:
This looks like as if you do use the same outgoing server for both accounts. Obviously this will work with the given credentials for one account only.

Check which account uses which SMTP server: In Account Settings - select the account name of the first account in the left pane. What is selected for 'Outgoing Server (SMTP)'? Please provide a screenshot.

Repeat this for the second account, and post your results (with screenshots).
creator: christ1

content:
There's only one outgoing server listed for both accounts. If I change the email address in one, it changes for both of them. At the end of the day I'm able to receive email now, and send from my main address so I'm happy unless there's an easy way to be able to send from both my addresses.

Thanks very much for your help christ1, it's much appreciated !  :-)
creator: colinfinbow

content:
I'm happy unless there's an easy way to be able to send from both my addresses.

All you need to do is to create a second SMTP server for the second account, with the credentials of the second account. Then link the new SMTP server to the second account. You've already got all pieces of the puzzle, you just need to put them together.

And this sending problem has got nothing to do with the original OAuth2 problem this topic is about. Most likely sending from both accounts never worked before.
creator: christ1

content:
anche la guida online lo indica ancora possibile :

Il pannello Intestazioni Il pannello delle intestazioni mostra le informazioni relative al messaggio selezionato, come le intestazioni Da, A, Oggetto, così come la data e l'ora del messaggio.

In questo pannello è possibile eseguire diverse azioni sul messaggio, come rispondere, inoltrare, archiviare o eliminare il messaggio, contrassegnarlo come indesiderato (spam) o come letto, aprire il messaggio in una conversazione o in una nuova scheda, visualizzare il sorgente del messaggio, salvare il messaggio o stamparlo. Se si desidera riordinare o rimuovere i pulsanti, fare clic tenendo premuto il tasto destro del mouse su uno dei pulsanti e successivamente fare clic su Personalizza… nel menu visualizzato. Verrà aperta la finestra di personalizzazione. Sarà quindi possibile trascinare i pulsanti presenti nel pannello delle intestazioni spostandoli nell'ordine desiderato;sarà inoltre possibile spostare i pulsanti trascinandoli e rilasciandoli nella finestra di personalizzazione per rimuoverli dal pannello, oppure trascinarli dalla finestra sulla barra del pannello delle intestazioni rilasciandoli nella posizione desiderata. In caso di errore o di ripensamenti, riaprire la finestra di personalizzazione e fare clic sul pulsante Ripristina predefiniti.

content: If your password is not working, then you need to check with your email provider for the password. If your password is working and you want to know what it is, check settings>privacy&security and click savedpasswords and then showpasswords. Then highlight the desired row and select edit (or copy) password.
creator: davidsk

content:
That's an okay solution for signatures, but don't most email readers block images by default if they're from unknown senders? And if I'm using the name of other First Nations peoples in the body of an email, your suggested solution doesn't resolve that concern either.

The topic of my thread asks specifically about words with non-English characters in personal dictionaries, not this one word in my signature file--which I only referenced as an example.

Thank you for thinking about this, though.
creator: TLRS

content:
Microsoft ha cambiato metodo di autenticazione ed ora richiede l'uso di Ouath2 -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/autenticazione-oauth-microsoft-thunderbird-2023

In alcuni casi inoltre bisogna aggiornare i server -> https://support.microsoft.com/it-it/office/impostazioni-pop-imap-e-smtp-per-outlook-com-d088b986-291d-42b8-9564-9c414e2aa040
creator: @next

content:
In the article you cited, it states the outgoing server must be smtp.office365.com. Using smtp-mail.outlook.com won't offer OAuth2 as an option. Similarly, the incoming must be outlook.office365.com.

Change the server to smtp.office365.com, and if OAuth2 still doesn't appear, restart TB.
creator: sfhowes

content: You can keep the messages and delete the account, if that is acceptable. That is, you could create local folders and copy the messages there. Then, check the local folders to verify that you've saved them, and then you could delete the account. There is no reliable way to keep the account and prevent checking for new messages.

content: You can select account settings and then select server settings and specify to leave messages on the server.
creator: davidsk

content: Thanks, but the problems with that is that the pop3 state is not saved on the server, but rather locally, so when I return from my trip and get "new" messages on the desktop after I use the other machine, I will get a profusion of messages that I have already processed and which got sorted into the folders on the machine that I read them on. Seems to me that leaving messages on the server only works if the server maintains state, and that would be IMAP, no?
creator: pb

content: Well, that wasn't part of your intended direction. Specifying to leave on server does achieve your goal, but accessing from different PCs does cause previously downloaded messages to download again. You're in a compromise situation. If you do not trust your ISP's server, your safest move (in my opinion) is to create a second account in IMAP and download everything (file>offline>download) and then copy all of it to local folders. That is, if you don't trust the ISP and if it goes bust, then you've lost everything. Then, you could continue to use the account from multiple PCs, knowing you had a full copy. And do backup if you take that route.
creator: davidsk

content:
Thanks. I guess I wasn't detailed enough in the question.

I believe that the last time I tried to create an imap account on a server where I had the same credentials for a pop3 account, thunderbird either would not or could not do it, possibly because the server would not allow it. So then I run into problems converting from pop3 to imap, which I haven't investigated.

But the problem still remains that since I will always want to keep email locally (if not only locally), although I would not download the same email twice, it seems that I would still somehow have to sync my locally-stored email between the two machines. Or am I missing something?
creator: pb
